justification: The article states: “Social Conservatism (Everett, 2013) 7-item scale. Participants indicate their warmth towards a set of policies.”
Under Table 1 the authors note: “Economic Conservatism (Everett, 2013) 5-item scale. Participants indicate their warmth towards a set of policies.”
Table 1 describes “Nationalism (Sidanius et al., 1997) 9-item scale” used for rating agreement with nationalist statements.
The measures list includes “Patriotism (Federico, Golec, & Dial, 2005) 9-item scale” assessing love of country.
Table 1 notes: “Authoritarianism (Hetherington & Weiler, 2009) 4-item scale. Participants indicate whether they believe children ought to be ‘obedient’, ‘respectful’, etc.”

measured_by: 4-item Social Dominance Orientation scale (Pratto et al., 2012)
justification: The article lists “Social Dominance Orientation (Pratto et al., 2012) 4-item scale” where participants rate statements about group equality.
Table 1 includes “System Justification (Kay & Jost, 2003) 8-item scale” with statements such as “American society is fair.”

measured_by: single-item question on importance of religion (Pew Research Center)
justification: Participants were asked: “How important is religion in your life?”—a single-item measure taken from the Pew Research Center.

measured_by: single-item question on prayer frequency (Pew Research Center)
justification: The survey asked: “Outside of attending religious services, how often do you pray?”—identifying prayer frequency as a single-item measure.

measured_by: single-item question on service attendance (Pew Research Center)
justification: Participants responded to: “Aside from weddings and funerals, how often do you attend religious services?” providing the attendance frequency measure.

measured_by: Extreme Pro-Group Actions 5-item scale (Swann et al., 2009)
justification: The supplemental materials specify: “Extreme Pro-Group Actions (Swann et al., 2009) 5-item scale” with items like willingness to fight for America.
The paper notes: “Dogmatism (Shearman & Levine, 2006) 11-item updated version of Altemeyer’s measure of dogmatism.”
The methods list the “Comprehensive Intellectual Humility Scale” measuring four facets of intellectual humility.

measured_by: drift rate parameter of the Drift-Diffusion Model
justification: The authors explain that the DDM produces “drift rate (corresponding to average rate of evidence accumulation)” from accuracy and RT data.

measured_by: threshold parameter of the Drift-Diffusion Model
justification: The same passage notes the DDM “threshold (corresponding to response caution in terms of speed-accuracy tradeoff).”

measured_by: non-decision time parameter of the Drift-Diffusion Model
justification: They also state the DDM provides “non-decision time (corresponding to the speed of perceptual stimulus processing and motor execution).”

measured_by: accuracy on the Keep Track task
justification: When describing task decomposition, the paper gives “accuracy scores (e.g., in the case of the Keep Track task that requires working memory)” as the dependent measure for working memory.
